step.context: \textbf{A theoretical question.} \\ \text{If }y = f(x) = \sqrt{\dfrac{a}{b}},\text{ then what is }\log y?
step.reason: \text{If you see an expression of the form } y = \left(\dfrac{a}{b}\right)^c,\\ \text{then consider taking log on both sides. The}\\ \text{resulting expression is usually easier to work}\\ \text{with. That said, }\\ \begin{align} \text{If } y &= \sqrt{m}\text{ then }\log y = \frac{1}{2}\log m \\ \text{and if } m &= \frac{a}{b}\text{ then }\log m = \log a - \log b \\ \implies \log y &= \frac{1}{2}\log m = \frac{1}{2}\cdot \left(\log a - \log b\right) \end{align}

step.context: \textbf{Getting comfortable with }\sum \\ \text{Which of the following correctly expresses }\\ \log y = \log f(x)?
step.reason: \sum_{i=1}^n T_i = T_1 + T_2 + \cdots + T_n.\text{ It is simply a}\\ \text{convenient way to write long expressions.} \\ \text{That said, we showed in Step 1 that }\\ \qquad \log y = \frac{1}{2}\cdot \left(\log a - \log b\right).\\ \begin{align} \therefore a &= (x-1)\cdot (x-2) \\ \implies \log a &= \log (x-1) + \log (x-2) \\ &= \sum_{i=1}^2\log (x-i) \\ \text{And }b &= (x-3)\cdot (x-4)\cdot (x-5) \\ \implies \log b &= \log (x-3) + \log (x-4) + \log (x-5) \\ &= \sum_{j=3}^5\log (x-j) \\ \implies \log y &= \frac{1}{2}\cdot \left(\log a - \log b\right) \\ &= \frac{1}{2}\cdot \left[\sum_{i=1}^2\log (x-i) - \sum_{j=3}^5\log (x-j)\right] \end{align}
